text_62f079d650a2321f8a8ba89b: I‚Äôm a UX Designer focused on building world class experiences.
text_62f983ef35be9f15b9368aec: The Bandwidth Customer Experience Team had long been using Pendo‚Äôs in-application guide functionality to surface guides to our users on more confusing topics and functions that were in the Bandwidth Dashboard interface (and still do today!). But users would often send in support tickets for our support team to guide them through a process that already had a guide tied to it.
text_62f983ef35be9f15b9368aee: Talking with a few customers and members of our support team, it became clear that the guides were extremely useful when the users saw them, but triggering guides was confusing and inconsistent across the board.
text_62f983ef35be9f15b9368af0: ‚ÄúSometimes I don‚Äôt want to read a guide the moment it pops up, so I just close out. But I would love to be able to re-launch that guide when I had more time to actually go through it‚Äù - Ralph Newman
text_62f983ef35be9f15b9368af2: The CX (customer experience) team and I decided it would be useful to leverage Pendo‚Äôs Resource Center product has a hub for our users to go to when they wanted guidance on one of the many features.
text_62f05a6f481a4aaf356bf10c: How might we (Bandwidth's Customer Experience Team) provide users training and support resources in a centralized location?
text_62f983ef35be9f15b9368af4: There were a few requirements that the new Resource Center had to meet in order to get the seal of UX approval. All Resource Center components must appear to be native within the Bandwidth Dashboard application. Style the Resource Center in a way that would mimic the current design system. Meet WCAG AA 2.0 accessibility standards.
text_62f05a6f481a4aaf356bf110: The goal of this project was to reduce the number of customer support tickets submitted asking for guidance about portal functionality that already had an existing tutorial. We compared number of these tickets submitted after the completion of the project to determine if fewer customers were requesting support, indicating customers were more successful in accessing the guides to resolving their questions.
text_62f05a6f481a4aaf356bf114:
I worked with the CX (customer experience) team to help create a system in which new and returning users would be able to access guides to features that they may not understand or just might have forgotten how to use. 

I began by researching what tools we had available to use and talking with the CX team about how they wanted to approach the solution to this problem. 

The conclusion was Pendo would be used to surface guides. We (Bandwidth) had already been using Pendo analytics services for a while so it was a natural decision to make use of a feature we were paying for but hadn‚Äôt actually used. Additionally, Pendo has the ability to contain guides in a ‚ÄúResource Center‚Äù. This would allow us to give users the ability to view and review a guide whenever they wanted. 

While members of the CX team focused on guide content (I‚Äôm not a writer), I began more research on how we could surface these guides to users. I did more research on how other companies had implemented similar solutions and began to create some early mockups of what ours could look like.
text_62f05a6f481a4aaf356bf118: Some early concepts of the ‚ÄúBandwidth Learning Lab‚Äù were made to show just how much we could accomplish using the resource center feature. Not only could we provide the guides that were needed to solve the problem, but we could also provide support directly from the learning lab itself. Potentially further reducing the number of support tickets that would be received.
text_62f05a6f481a4aaf356bf11c: As higher fidelity iterations were made and presented to the CX team to review, I began some user testing with my mockups so I could see how the learning lab changed the way that users would interact with support if they had the option to chat live within their web browser.
text_62f05a6f481a4aaf356bf11e: If i can find the results of LL testing
text_62f05a6f481a4aaf356bf120: The results were clear and unsurprising (to me at least). Users much preferred having the option to connect with support over a live chat service rather than picking up the phone and calling a support rep. Unfortunately the CX and support teams didn‚Äôt have the capacity to restructure their operations to support live chat, so we didn‚Äôt ultimately follow through with the feature in final designs.
text_62f05a6f481a4aaf356bf124:
Once all stakeholders agreed on the content and features to be included in the learning lab, I tightened up the design for final approval.

Pendo did not have the ability to easily style their resource center product. This meant that we had to get creative with styling the resource center. 

It ended up falling on me to find some loopholes in the Pendo system to be able to implement the CSS of the design that I had created. Pendo reps pointed me in the direction of the files I needed to find and edit, and I did the rest.
text_62f05a6f481a4aaf356bf128: After it was all said and done, we ended up hitting the key result. Our work had successfully reduced the number of support tickets that we received while also providing users with some new options for getting in touch with support (even though live chat wasn‚Äôt one of them).
text_62f05a6f481a4aaf356bf12a:
Our rep at Pendo was impressed by how we were able to completley customize their product to fit our use case. They asked me and a CX team member to give a presentation at one of their webinars on how we were able to accomplish this task by only using the limited number of tools the resource center product had to offer. 

You can check out the full presentation by clicking the button below!
text_62f05a6f481a4aaf356bf12e:
Many of the challenges from this project were from factors outside of my control dictating what had to be done. But not when it came to the design of the learning lab. Having overwhelming data that showed our users craved live chat and not implementing that feature was pretty devastating for me.

 It felt like such an easy win for everyone involved (I talked with internal support reps who wanted to spend less time on the phone). But I had to let go of that concept for that project and just continue to advocate for its value. 

The resource center product from Pendo having limited customizability was also a huge obstacle to overcome. There was a good chunk of time where we thought we would have to buy a new tool all together to actually accomplish our mission. Only after doing some deep diving with Pendo support for weeks did we actually realize that our design could be implemented......just extremely painfully.
text_62faf19902f1138386d1c894: Throughout my time working on designs and flows for UI products at Bandwidth, I‚Äôve learned a great deal about how to ensure my designs follow an established pattern that our users expect. Through trial and error and many design reviews with teammates, I collected a knowledge of patterns that only one other person in the company shares in its entirety!
text_62faf19902f1138386d1c896: This approach for documenting our design system worked for most problems that we encountered as a UX team. New designers would learn through knowledge sharing from me and others and gradually ramp up their own knowledge.
text_62faf19902f1138386d1c898: But when Bandwidth acquired another sister company in the market, we suddenly had became responsible for a whole separate UI product with a completely different design system AND no extra inherited designers üôÉ
text_62faf19902f1138386d1c89a: Realizing that our team‚Äôs old system of documentation wouldn‚Äôt be applicable to this new product, I took it upon myself to create a design system to systematically document and explain each component that was in this foreign product.
text_62faf18f036a8a065286e758: The result of this endevor is called BluePrint. Its the Bandwidth UX Team‚Äô s design library that is setting the new foundation for future products and services that Bandwidth builds!
text_62f05ac0f475e74ce5ffd82a: How might we learn and design for a new product with minimal design knowledge from stakeholders?
text_62f05ac0f475e74ce5ffd82e: UX Team designers are able to produce and document designs that follow a pattern of established styles and flows.
text_62f05ac0f475e74ce5ffd832: For the first few months of designing flows in the newly aquired UI, our manager had assigned a teammate to be the sole designer. When product managers would come to us with designs requests for their new features or updates that they wanted to make in this new portal, they would all go to 1 person.
text_62faf68e5c58cf76c2d4c8f2:
Naturally, this became overwhelming for one designer and eventually the whole team had to start pitching in to help. 

This is when I thought to myself ‚Äúwow, I really have no idea what rules I‚Äôm supposed to follow or even what components I have to work with‚Äù
text_62faf68e5c58cf76c2d4c8f3: This began my research into how other companies and designers kept track of their designs and maintained consistency throughout products. I stumbled across the concept of design systems and how companies and UX teams use them to achieve exactly.
text_62faf68e5c58cf76c2d4c8f4: While design systems themselves aren't a brand new concept, they are just starting to become recognized enough in the tech world to be integral to company branding and functionality.
text_62faf68e5c58cf76c2d4c8f5: Design systems flex the maturity of design at companies and users and consumers are becoming more aware daily of the impact design has on the products and tools that they love.
text_62faf68e5c58cf76c2d4c8f6: After doing heaps of research to determine exactly what design systems are and what value they bring, it became clear that Bandwidth could benefit from incorporating a design system. Bandwidth has been shifting toward more design-thinking and I realized that a design system could become a key part in that transformation.
text_62faf695eb7de6de50a6ee37: I began systematically re-creating every component that the UX team could find in a brand new figma library. I did this first so the rest of the team could have immediate access to a consistent set of components to work with in their designs.
text_62faf8086ec1ac009fee9929: Then, I worked to create a documentation system that I could go through for each component I had created and determine how it was made and where and how it was used within a UI product.
text_62faf8086ec1ac009fee992a: Once I had a solid base of components and documentation, I created another figma template file that would hold each of those newly created components and styles. The template is key because it allows team members to get a fantastic foundation for starting new projects, while also having some guidance on how and where to use components.
text_62faf8086ec1ac009fee992b: Now that I had a great collection of tools for designers to use, I had to document all my work in a way that could be accessible to anyone outside the UX team. It took me a good amount of time to research solutions for documentation. Should I just host the figma template file? Should I use an internal tool like Confluence? Should I just make a slack channel and pin a google sheet to it? None of these options inspired me.
text_62faf8086ec1ac009fee992c:
But then I discovered Zeroheight!

A tool built from the ground up to document design systems. It allowed me to sync up my figma files that I had already created while also letting me do cooler things like add rules for using components and even writing or uploading my own code to showcase components!
text_62f05ac0f475e74ce5ffd83c: The biggest challenge I faced in this project was not one that I expected. It wasn‚Äôt the tedious amount of documenation I had to do. It wasn‚Äôtme  being the pixel perfect peter pestering other designers to make sure they were using my new shiny components right....It was convincing others (in and outside of my team) that a design system was something that we needed to ensure consistency in our products.
text_62faf9beb4a90a702606e539: I could and can see the huge value that this sort of tool could bring to the company. But conveying that idea was so much harder than I thought it would be. It boiled down to countless hours of research and constantly showing and explaining examples of what design systems did for other companies.
text_62fafaadd139c83b976579c9: While this story isnt over yet I‚Äôm confident that my design library will be the future for all of Bandwidth‚Äôs products and even potentially influence the future iteration of Bandwidth‚Äôs brand identity.

text_62f0623329393960f3eb3f04: Bandwidth GUI products have lots of edge cases that need to be accounted for when designing. Because of this, there are many UI inconsistencies throughout.
text_62f0623329393960f3eb3f08: Produce and document a design system to allow for UX designers and developers to create and implement designs while following a pattern of established flows and patterns.  ------ create a new design system for Bandwidth‚Äôs integrated platform.
text_62f0623329393960f3eb3f0c:
The inspiration for this project was born from several different problems that my (UX) team was facing. 

We were struggling to make sure that new designers were following practices and patterns that had been established because none of those decisions were documented. When designs were being handed over to developers, if there wasn‚Äôt an explicit mockup of every single interaction for ever signle component, then errors would happen. 

On top of this,  Bandwidth had recently aquired another company that had their own GUI which my team of 3 people had now inherited. So now, on top of having to teach new designers and developers about how to implement and design using the undocumented system, we now had to teach ourselves about the new interface and learn how to design for that system as well.
text_62f0623329393960f3eb3f10:
I saw this as impossible with our current method of design. Something had to change and we had to start designing for something new. 

I took it upon myself to start re-creating everything in the new GUI (lovingly reffered to as Portal 2) so that the team can start designing using those new components. 

As I was recreating the components, I would find myself trying to figure out how each of them was used in Portal 2. My progress would slow down exponentially when I did this. So I decided that when I had finished creating each new component, I would go through Portal 2 and determine where and how each component was used. 

Once I had a decently full sheet of documentation for each compoent, I needed a platform to showcase the documentation. To allow designers, developers, and anyone else the opprotunity to learn about the paterns that were used in Portal 2 and how to keep new designs inline with those patterns.

Using Zeroheight, I was able to produce a design system that seemed like it had been built from the ground up with care and attention put into every detail of every flow and component. But when it was actually just a recreation of what already existed. 

We would use this version of the design system (we called BluePrint v0.5) to lay out the foundation of what we wanted our future design system to be. Testing it with other designers and devs, we were able to determine what the design system covered well and identify places where it lacked. Using this information the UX team would be able to start iterating on layouts, components and flows to further improve not only the usability of Portal 2, but of the design system as well.
text_62f0623329393960f3eb3f16: Obviously one of the biggest challenges here was the amount of information and learning that needed to be done to understand Portal 2. Learning and documenting it would prove extremely challenge but also an exercise in determing what design decision were made and for what reasons they were made. This would prove ultimately just as useful as the documentation itself as we could better determine the problems that the designs were trying to solve and further iterate on them.
text_62f062b4fd0ee8a467e8f9f4: I‚Äôm a UX Designer focused on building world class experiences.
text_62fa387f28a9586255be94c2: My name is Braxton Coats. I was born and raised in Raleigh, North Carolina and attended Sanderson Highschool. Upon graduation from highschool I was accepted into Appalachian State University where I would go on to graduate with a BS in Computer Science.
text_62fa387f28a9586255be94c6: I fell in love with design completely by accident. College was difficult for me as programming didn‚Äôt come easy to me and I really had to put in extra effort to be able to pass my classes. Senior year comes around and I have no real world experience as the anxiety of underperforming in a software engineering internship was terrifying. So I decided to throw my hat in the ring of some other internships that were in the same general field as computer science. A UX internship at Bandwidth was one of those internships... Without knowing what UX even was, I applied. After a long week of finals and a very short interview, I learned I had landed the UX internship!
text_62fa387f28a9586255be94c8: The internship at Bandwidth revealed to me my passion for design. I had never known people have jobs that completely focus on the user and how to make sure their experience is as pleasant and easy as possible. This discovery led me to pursue design for the rest of my time in college and to continue my passion full time has a UX Designer at Bandwidth.
